{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3343015,"name":"Jim Barstow","username":"JimB1918","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jimb1918/{size}/166841_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-25T18:34:35.144Z","cooked":"

While it is still too soon to count us out yet, for the first time in a long while (ever?), NC GEARS did not qualify for MSC.
Although this is disappointing, I wanted to share insights to our post-events analysis of our season, hopefully to help newer teams analyze their own successes and failures and grow from their season.

While we ultimately failed to gather enough state ranking points to qualify for MSC, we identified the following things that went well (plusses), and things we can work on in the future (deltas).

Plusses (aka “The Good”):

  • NCSwerve Gen5 - drive powerplant updated to Kraken X60
  • NCSwerve Gen5 - updated gearing to 5.66M/s, a significant speed increase from previous generations
  • NCSwerve Gen5 - re-designed bearing caps and encoder housing, improving access to things and eliminating data cables becoming disconnected
  • NCSwerve Gen5 - added drive-belt idler for belt tensioning (rather than moving the drive assembly)
  • Pose/Odometry - Re-worked entire pose system with a dedicated pose supplier class which handles pose math and target tracking
  • Pose/Vision - Overhauled Vision management to update pose handler with updates from vision
  • Target Tracking - Proved out new method of tracking targets based on odometry calculations rather than active targeting, allowing for development of shooting-on-the-fly calculations
  • Triggers - Reworked large amounts of conditional state code into triggers, allowing for autonomous or semi-autonomous functions to handle parts of the robots functionality
  • Synced/Fused encoders - Tested and proved the efficacy of fused/syned sensors, greatly improving the zeroing and position accuracy of systems
  • Phoenix6 - migrated all (where possible) systems to Phoenix6, greatly improving the simplicity and repeatability of position and velocity controls
  • SysId - Learned how to properly characterize motor systems to reduce time to find the appropriate gains
  • Code/Software - Overall code/software improvements dramatically reducing complexity of code, added lots of comments to help code self-document
  • Wiring - Meticulous care of wiring (hot glue for Wiedmullers, ferrules on wires, retention clips in powerpoles) all lead to minimal/no electrical issues this season.
  • Scouting - Overhaul of our scouting app codebase and data management should provide a good base for future modifications
  • Spirit - Organized cheers? Check. Make it loud? Check. Theme based concert poster? Check. Beatles inspired robot name and costumes? Check. Our spirit has been getting some love, and people enjoy it.

Deltas (aka “The Bad”):

  • Shooter/Flywheel gearing - Learned the importance of calculating more appropriate gearing for shooters to keep the target velocity in the power band of the motors
  • Position control gearing - identified issue when using upduction for position control reducing the accuracy of aiming. Using appropriate reduction gearing to improve stability of aiming would be an improvement.
  • In-path sensors - working with mechanical team to better identify game-piece path sensor locations would increase the ability to make smart decisions about parts at the earliest possible points could lead to better failure resolution.
  • Weidmullers - Depressing the button on these connectors when inserting wires provides a much better retention of ferruled connectors (Thanks Comets 3357 for the explanation of why…)
  • Mechanical/Software cooperation - Earlier and more frequent discussions between the mechanical design and the software/sensor design will lead to more robust systems and designs.
  • Spirit - The wacky waving inflatable arm flailing tube man from Al Harrington’s wacky waving inflatable arm flailing tube man emporium and warehouse went home with someone last season. We will remedy this situation.

Things we learned the hard way (aka “The Ugly”):

  • The RoboRio 1.0 has a tangible memory limit and no swap space. Eventually, your robot code reaches critical mass and consumes 107% memory, crashing. Switching to RoboRio 2.0 solves this. Pay attention to memory usage (until 2027 control system)
  • Carpet-ripples have a non-zero height that stacks up with other assembly things that may not be on the drawings, account for more clearance when planning to drive under non-moving objects.

Undoubtedly, there is a bunch I missed, I will try to come back here and keep this updated as I think of others. Feel free to discuss and ask about some of these, as I am happy to share what we learned and what worked.

We always learn a lot from watching you guys work, it’s a shame we won’t get to pick your brains some more next week. The machines you build are always so much fun to look at and see how they come together, but the work behind the scenes is more impressive. I had some great talks with a few students and mentors at West Michigan last weekend.

I look forward to seeing the return of your wacky wavy inflatable arm guy when we compete next.

It is likely that many of us will be meandering about Saginaw in volunteer shirts, donning our NC GEARS buttons somewhere on our person. I will make a point to swing by and chat since I will likely not be frantically re-writing bits of code.
